comment: Here white resigned. Nearly all moves lead to a serious loss of material. After a pawn move or two, white will face complete Zugzwang. Zugzwang is a German word meaning 'a compulsion to move.' White is forced to move, and in so doing will lose. If white plays 26. Rc1 or Rd1 then 26... Re2 wins white's Queen. If 26. Kh2 then 26... R5f3 also wins white's Queen. If 26. g4 then 26... R5f3 27. Bxf3 Rh2 is checkmate. If 26. Bc1 then 26... Bxb1 wins material. If 26. a3 then 26... a5. etc.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player by detailing the potential losses in material and the resulting checkmate situations that could follow after the pawn move.
moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. g3 Bb7 5. Bg2 Be7 6. Nc3 O-O 7. O-O d5 8. Ne5 c6 9. cxd5 cxd5 10. Bf4 a6 11. Rc1 b5 12. Qb3 Nc6 13. Nxc6 Bxc6 14. h3 Qd7 15. Kh2 Nh5 16. Bd2 f5 17. Qd1 b4 18. Nb1 Bb5 19. Rg1 Bd6 20. e4 fxe4 21. Qxh5 Rxf2 22. Qg5 Raf8 23. Kh1 R8f5 24. Qe3 Bd3 25. Rce1 h6
context: This is a game between Saemisch, Friedrich GM (as White) and Nimzovich, Aron GM (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Pawn to h6
reformulated: White resigned due to strategic disadvantages. Moving the pawn or two would lead to a severe loss of material. In the resulting positions, Black would either force White into Zugzwang, where White's move would lead to a loss, or directly capture White's Queen through a series of moves. Black secures the Queen with 26... Re2, 26... R5f3, or 26... R5f3 followed by 27. Bxf3 Rh2. Additionally, Black gains material with 26... Bxb1. Lastly, White's attempt to hold the position with 26. a3 allows Black to counter with 26... a5, worsening White's position.
